                      Cedartown, GA Plant 





















                      I.  Executive Summary
         1.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY

                        RESPONSE POLICIES





At GEO Specialty Chemical's Plant in Cedartown, GA., we are committed to operating and

maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and

responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and

emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the

public as well as protection of the environment.  This section of the document provides a brief

overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and

implemented, including:



 A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation

 A summary of results from our assessment of the potential off site consequences from

accidental chemical releases

 An overview of our accidental release prevention programs

 A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule

 An overview of our emergency response program

 An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical

releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

 The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires us to provide

 The detailed information (called data elements) about our risk management program







          2.0 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES





Our facility produces condensed naphthalene sulfonates under the trade name of LOMAR, alkyl

naphthalene sulfonates, defoamers and miscellaneous other organic chemicals.  In all, about 250

different products are manufactured at the Cedartown plant, using about 250  raw materials.  



In our processes, we use the following chemicals that EPA h

as identified as having the potential

to cause off site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:



TOXICS



Oleum               CAS# 7446-11-9 Maximum Inventory        361,000 pounds



Used in the production of sulfonated naphthalene intermediates; the precursor

for all LOMAR products as well as the alkyl sulfonated naphthalenes.





Formaldehyde        CAS# 50-00-0        Maximum Inventory        305,000 pounds



Used in the condensation reaction step of the LOMAR products and alkyl

sulfonated naphthalenes.  Smaller quantities are used in other products.





Cyclohexylamine     CAS# 102-71-2       Maximum Inventory        50,000 pounds



Used in the neutralization step of certain alkyl naphthalene sulfonates.





FLAMMABLES



Propane   CAS# 74-98-6        Maximum Inventory        102,000

pounds



Used as a fuel for various industrial trucks and as a backup source of heat in the

event of a curtailment in the supply of natural gas.



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts

help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the

public, and the environment by our use of these chemicals.







          3.0 KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS





EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenarios and

alternative release scenarios for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these

scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to

limit the exposure distances for each scenario:





Worst-case Release Scenario   Regulated Toxic Chemical - Oleum



The worst case scenario is a catastrophic failure of the largest storage tank with its maximum

allowable inventory (361,000 pounds) spilled into a dike of 1,200 sq. ft. under the atmospheric

conditions prescribed by the regulation.



Wind speed - 1.5 meters/second          Temperature - 25 C

Stability Class - F

Relative Humidity - 50.0%



The estimated distance to the toxic exposure end point is 0.43 miles from the tank.  The off site

impact could affect up to 50 residences.  Also within the 0.43 mile radius are: Purks Elementary

School, with 400 students, Stone-Smurfit Corporation and several other businesses and churches.



The only passive mitigation in this scenario is the containment dike, which limits the exposed

surface area.  The plant also has a white mineral oil system that can be used to blanket the oleum,

inhibiting the release of fumes from any spills inside the dike.





Alternative Release Scenario   Regulated Toxic Chemical - Oleum



The alternate scenario is the rupture or severance of the pipeline used for unloading rail cars into

the storage tank.  This would result in the uncontrolled release of oleum at a rate of 100 gallons

per minute for approximately two minutes onto the paved lot between the car and the tank.  The

atmospheric conditions, as prescribed by the regulation, would be:



Wind speed - 1.5 meters/second          Temperature - 25 C

Stability Class - F                Relative Humidity - 50.0%



The estimated distance to the exposure end point is 0.31 miles from the tank.  The off site impact

would affect up to 30 residences.  Stone-Smurfit Corporation is within the 0.31 mile radius.  Purks 

elementary school and most of the churches and other businesses are not affected under this

scenario.



Mitigation controls on this scenario are a low flow alarm and shutoff on the unloading pump,

slopes and interceptor drains that would limit the exposed surface area of the liquid and valves

that are normally kept closed to keep the liquid in the trenches.





Alternative Release Scenario   Regulated Toxic Chemical - Formaldehyde



The alternate scenario is the rupture or severance of the pipeline used for unloading rail cars into

the storage tank.  This would result in the uncontrolled release of formaldehyde at a rate o

f 100

gallons per minute for approximately two minutes onto the paved lot between the car and the tank. 

The atmospheric conditions would be:



Wind speed - 1.5 meters/second          Temperature - 25 C

Stability Class - F                Relative Humidity - 50.0%



The estimated distance to the exposure end point is 0.19 miles from the tank.  The off site impact

would affect up to 10 residences.  Stone-Smurfit Corporation is within the 0.19 mile radius.  Purks 

elementary school and the chrches and other businesses are not affected under this scenario.



Mitigation controls on this scenario are a low flow alarm and shutoff on the unloading pump,

slopes and interceptor drains that would limit the exposed surface area of the liquid and valves

that are normally kept closed to keep the liquid in the trenches.





Alternative Release Scenario   Regulated Toxic Chemical - Cyclohexylamine



The alternate scenario is the rupture or severance of the pipeline used for unloading tank wagons

into the storage tank.  This would result in the uncontrolled release of cyclohexylamine at a rate of

100 gallons per minute for approximately two minutes onto the paved lot between the tank wagon 

and the WWTP spill collection basin.  The atmospheric conditions would be:



Wind speed - 1.5 meters/second          Temperature - 25 C

Stability Class - F                Relative Humidity - 50.0%



The estimated distance to the exposure end point is 0.18 miles from the tank.  The off site impact

would affect up to 10 residences.  Stone-Smurfit Corporation is within the 0.18 mile radius.  Purks 

elementary school and the chrches and other businesses are not affected under this scenario.



Mitigation controls on this scenario are a low flow alarm and shutoff on the unloading pump,

slopes and interceptor drains that would limit the exposed surface area of the liquid and valves

that are normally kept closed to keep the liquid in the trenches.





Worst-case Release Scenario

Regulated Flammable Chemical - Propane



The worst case scenario is a vapor cloud explosion following the catastrophic failure of the only

storage tank at its maximum allowable inventory (102,000 pounds) under the atmospheric

conditions prescribed by the regulation.



Wind speed - 1.5 meters/second          Temperature - 25 C

Stability Class - F                Relative Humidity - 50.0%



The estimated distance to the 1.0 psi overpressure end point is 0.38 miles from the tank.  The off

site impact would affect up to 100 residences and Stone-Smurfit Corporation.



There is no mitigation in this scenario.





Alternative Release Scenario   Regulated Flammable Chemical - Propane



The alternate scenario is the failure of a one inch diameter transfer line at the propane vaporizer

causing a vapor cloud explosion.  The atmospheric conditions would be:



Wind speed - 1.5 meters/second          Temperature - 25 C

Stability Class - F                Relative Humidity - 50.0%



The estimated distance to the exposure end point is 0.15 miles from the tank.  There would be no

off site impact.



We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the

community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.







        4.0 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS





We take a systematic, proactive approach to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. 

Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs

including:



 Process safety information

 Process hazard analysis

 Operating procedures

 Training

 Mechanical integrity

 Management of change

 Pre-startup review

 Compliance audits

 Incident investigation

 Employee participation

 Hot work permit

 Contractors





As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention

steps:



  Performed a hazard an

alysis on all components of the processes which use any of the

regulated chemicals and made changes to equipment, instruments and operating procedures to

minimize the potential for incidents;

  Operating procedures are reviewed annually by operators and supervisors to make sure that

they are current and to clarify anything that could be confusing or misinterpreted;

  New operators are thoroughly trained before operating the equipment and all operators

undergo refresher training every eighteen months;

  Major changes to the plant were reviewed by engineers, supervisors and operators before the

new equipment was started;

  All recommendations made during the most recent audit were implemented within two months.





These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental

chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these

management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and

controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.







                  5.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY





We keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  During

the past five years there were no accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under

EPA's RMP rule that resulted in injuries, significant property damage, or environmental damage

either on site or off site.











                  6.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM





We have a written Emergency Response Plan that addresses the requirements of OSHA and the

EPA for the safety and protection of our employees and the community.  We also maintain a spill

contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory

requirements for emergency notification.  Our program provides the essential planning and

training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment durin

g emergency

situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan.







              7.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY





The following is a list of improvements that we are planning to implement at the facility to help

prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



Evaluate the feasibility passive and active mitigation systems that will reduce the impact of the

worst case and alternate scenarios for all of the regulated chemicals.



Use administrative controls to reduce the maximum amount of propane on site.



Continue updating the Emergency Response Plan in a way that will make it easier for personnel

responding from off site to understand and use.



Conduct drills with our plant's Hazmat team and the Cedartown Fire Department.
